Article Title: Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella ‘warns’ employees at company townhall: ‘I’m haunted by one particular…’
Article Text:
Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella

Nadella cautions employees about future of technology



Biggest Tech Layoffs of 2025: Job Cuts at TCS, Intel, Microsoft, Google and more





Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella has revealed that he is “haunted” by the possibility of Microsoft not surviving the era of artificial intelligence (AI). Speaking at an employee-only town hall, Nadella was responding to a question about a perceived change in the company's culture, but his answer also exposed his personal fears about the company's future.“Some of the biggest businesses we’ve built might not be as relevant going forward,” Nadella said in the town hall last week, as per The Verge.He cited Digital Equipment Corporation (DEC) as a cautionary tale of a once-dominant tech company that disappeared after it failed to adapt to new technologies like the Reduced Instruction Set Computing (RISC) architecture.“Our industry is full of case studies of companies that were great once, that just disappeared. I’m haunted by one particular one called DEC,” said Nadella, adding that DEC, a leader in the early 1970s, faced competition from IBM and others, making it irrelevant.The CEO, who said his first computer was a DEC VAX and that he always wanted to work there, reflected on what it takes for a company to not only thrive but to continue attracting top talent.“Some of the people who contributed to Windows NT came from a DEC lab that was laid off,” Nadella noted. His remarks were made in response to an employee from the UK who described the company's atmosphere as “markedly different, colder, more rigid, and lacking in the empathy we have come to value.”The Microsoft CEO recently told employees that the company needs to “do better” in rebuilding trust with its workforce, while accepting a perceived lack of empathy in the company’s culture“I deeply appreciate that, the question and the sentiment behind it. I take it as feedback for me and everyone in the leadership team, because at the end of the day, I think we can do better, and we will do better,” as per an audio obtained by CNBC.
Article Summary: Nadella was responding to a question about a perceived change in the company's culture. He cited Digital Equipment Corporation as a cautionary tale of a once- dominant tech company that disappeared after it failed to adapt to new technologies. Nadella said his first computer was a DEC VAX and he always wanted to work there.

Article Title: President Donald Trump to Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang: 'I hope you're right… all I can say'
Article Text:
Trump and Starmer sign ‘ Tech Prosperity Deal ’



Nvidia , Google and Microsoft commits billions in UK investment

US President Donald Trump publicly expressed his awe and limited understanding of artificial intelligence (AI), saying the technology is “taking over the world” during a state visit to Britain. His remarks came as he and British Prime Minister Keir Starmer hosted a meeting with tech and business leaders, including Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang.Trump addressed the tech leaders, specifically singling out Huang, saying, “I'm looking at you guys. You're taking over the world. Jensen, I don't know what you're doing here.” His comments drew laughter from the audience and Starmer. Trump concluded his thought by stating, “I hope you're right. All I can say is, we both hope you're right.”Following his remarks, Trump and Starmer signed a new "Tech Prosperity Deal" to boost collaboration between the US and Britain. The pact includes joint efforts to develop AI models for healthcare, expand quantum computing capabilities, and streamline civil nuclear projects.Before signing the document, Trump humorously asked his Treasury Secretary, Scott Bessent, for his approval.“Should I sign this?” Trump asked. He then joked, "Are you sure Scott? If the deal's no good, I'm blaming you, Scott," before putting pen to paper.As part of the deal, Nvidia committed to its largest rollout in Europe to date, deploying 120,000 graphics processing units across Britain. Huang predicted that the country will become an “AI superpower”.Notably, both Google and Microsoft also said that they will invest in the UK, with Microsoft CEO Saty Nadella announcing the biggest single investment – a $30 billion spending package – its largest ever outside the US.Google's parent company, Alphabet, also announced a $6.8 billion investment in UK artificial intelligence. This funding will support infrastructure and scientific research over the next two years, the company said. According to Google's chief investment officer, Ruth Porat, the UK offers “profound opportunities” for its work in advanced science.

A suspected North Korean hacking group has used ChatGPT to create a deepfake of a South Korean military ID card, a report claims. According to cybersecurity researchers, these fake IDs was reportedly used to make a phishing attempt more credible by linking to malware that could extract data from the recipient's device. The cyber-espionage unit, which researchers have dubbed Kimsuky, is suspected of being sponsored by North Korea and has been linked to other spying efforts against South Korean targets. The US Department of Homeland Security previously stated that Kimsuky is likely tasked by the North Korean regime with a global intelligence-gathering mission. The details were published in a report by the South Korean cybersecurity firm Genians.During their investigation into forged identification documents, Genians researchers tested ChatGPT. While the system initially refused to generate a government ID (which is illegal under South Korean law) however, adjusting the prompt allowed the restriction to be bypassed.Mun Chong-hyun, director at Genians said that the broader trend shows how attackers are turning to AI for tasks such as planning attacks, developing malware, creating hacking tools, and impersonating recruiters.In July, cybersecurity firm Genians shared its latest findings on signs of suspected North Korean operatives using AI in intelligence-gathering.Later on, in August, Anthropic reported that North Korean hackers had leveraged its Claude Code tool to secure remote jobs at US Fortune 500 tech companies. The AI system assisted them in crafting fake identities, passing coding tests, and even delivering technical work once hired.Earlier, in February, the company said it had banned accounts linked to North Korea that were using its service to generate fraudulent resumes, cover letters, and social media content to support recruitment schemes.Recent phishing attempts targeted South Korean journalists, researchers, and human rights activists focusing on North Korea. Emails appeared to come from an address ending in .mli.kr, mimicking a South Korean military domain. The number of victims remains unclear.US officials have long accused North Korea of running cyber operations, cryptocurrency theft, and IT contracting schemes to collect intelligence and generate revenue. Washington alleges that the funds support Pyongyang’s efforts to evade sanctions and advance its nuclear weapons program.

The United States and China announced they have reached a "framework" agreement to transfer TikTok to US-controlled ownership, potentially averting a ban of the popular social media app just days before a September 17 deadline. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent confirmed the preliminary deal during trade talks in Madrid, saying President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping will finalize the agreement in a Friday phone call.The framework would shift ownership of TikTok's US operations away from Chinese parent company ByteDance to American investors, addressing national security concerns that have dominated the app's future for years. While Bessent declined to reveal commercial terms, calling it a deal "between two private parties," he emphasized the agreement protects US security interests while preserving what Chinese negotiators consider the app's cultural characteristics.Trump celebrated the breakthrough on Truth Social, writing that "a deal was also reached on a 'certain' company that young people in our Country very much wanted to save."The announcement comes after months of negotiations and three deadline extensions since Trump took office, with the current ban scheduled to take effect Wednesday if no agreement is reached.Chinese trade negotiator Li Chenggang confirmed the two sides reached a "basic framework consensus" on resolving TikTok-related issues through cooperation. However, he warned the US against continued "suppression" of Chinese companies while seeking Chinese accommodation on American concerns.Critical details remain unresolved, including whether ByteDance will transfer control of TikTok's valuable recommendation algorithm that drives user engagement. Chinese officials previously expressed reluctance to export the algorithm technology, which Beijing considers strategically sensitive. Wang Jingtao from China's cyberspace regulator suggested the deal could involve licensing intellectual property rights rather than full transfer.Any final agreement may require approval from Congress, which passed bipartisan legislation in 2024 requiring ByteDance to divest TikTok or face a ban due to national security fears. The law, upheld by the Supreme Court, prohibits companies from "foreign adversary" countries from owning more than 20 percent of the platform.Industry analysts expect Oracle co-founder Larry Ellison, a Trump ally whose company currently hosts TikTok's US data, to lead the American investor group. TikTok serves approximately 170 million US users, making it one of the most significant social media platforms in the country.
Article Summary: The United States and China announced they have reached a "framework" agreement to transfer TikTok to US-controlled ownership. The agreement could avert a ban of the popular social media app just days before a September 17 deadline. The framework would shift ownership of TikTok's US operations away from Chinese parent company ByteDance.

Article Title: China's DeepSeek that 'shocked' America and US technology companies reveals actual cost of training AI model
Article Text:
Chinese AI DeepSeek model

Why DeepSeek and its model made waves in US tech industry



iPhone Air and iPhone 17 Series Mega Unboxing





Chinese AI developer DeepSeek has revealed the cost of training its R1 model, a figure that is significantly lower than those reported by its US rivals. After launch, the DeepSeek R1 model stood out for its cost-efficient development and its open-source nature, offering unlimited free usage to a wide audience. Its emergence as a direct competitor to models from industry leaders such as OpenAI Google , and Anthropic has brought new scrutiny to the financial investments required for AI development.According to a report by Reuters, DeepSeek revealed that the company spent a significantly low amount—just $294,000—to train its R1 model. This figure was published in a peer-reviewed article in the academic journal Nature.The company’s disclosure may reignite a debate in the tech industry over why US giants are spending hundreds of millions of dollars to train large language models (LLMs).DeepSeek's release of what it claimed were lower-cost AI systems in January caused investors to sell off tech stocks, as they worried the new models could threaten the dominance of companies like Nvidia. The update, which is the first cost estimate the Hangzhou-based company has released for its R1 model, appeared in a paper co-authored by its founder, Liang Wenfeng.The paper specified that the reasoning-focused model was trained using 512 Nvidia H800 chips.By comparison, OpenAI CEO Sam Altman said in 2023 that "foundational model training" had cost "much more" than $100 million, though his company has not provided detailed figures, Reuters reported.Some of DeepSeek's previous claims about its development costs and technology have been questioned by US companies and officials. The company’s use of H800 chips comes after the US in October 2022 made it illegal for Nvidia to export its more powerful H100 and A100 AI chips to China.In a supplementary document to the Nature article, DeepSeek acknowledged for the first time that it does own A100 chips and used them in the “preparatory stages of development” for R1.US officials claimed in June that DeepSeek had access to “large volumes” of H100 chips procured after export controls were in place, a claim Nvidia has denied, stating that DeepSeek used lawfully acquired H800 chips.
Article Summary: Chinese AI developer DeepSeek has revealed the cost of training its R1 model, a figure that is significantly lower than those reported by its US rivals. The company’s disclosure may reignite a debate in the tech industry over why US giants are spending hundreds of millions of dollars to train large language models.

Article Title: Mark Zuckerberg’s Elon Musk moment: Watch CEO’s ‘awkward’ moment when Meta Glasses live demo failed

What exactly happened with during Meta Ray-Ban Display glasses demo



Elon Musk’s Tesla Cybertruck fail



iPhone Air and iPhone 17 Series Mega Unboxing

The failed demo quickly went viral, with some observers drawing comparisons to the infamous on-stage "armor glass" shattering incident at the Tesla Cybertruck launch that shocked Elon Musk The Meta Ray-Ban Display glasses feature a heads-up display on the right lens to show notifications and directions, a major upgrade from previous models. The accompanying neural wristband is designed to allow users to control the glasses with subtle hand gestures.During the demo, Zuckerberg successfully used the wristband to send text messages to Meta CTO Andrew Bosworth. However, when he attempted to initiate a video call using a hand gesture, the system failed to respond. This happened even after several attempts.“That’s too bad,” Zuckerberg said, adding, “ I don’t know what happened.”Bosworth eventually joined him on stage, commenting on the poor Wi-Fi connection. Zuckerberg admitted the moment was unexpected, saying, “We'll debug that later. You practice these things like 100 times, and then you never know what's going to happen.”The video of the failed demo quickly spread on social media like Musk-owned X (formerly Twitter), prompting a range of reactions from X users.One user commented that the Wi-Fi excuse was "not really believable," while another joked about seeing the "raw uncut footage" of Zuckerberg's reaction afterward.In 2019, Musk was presenting the Cybertruck and during the live demo, lead designer Franz von Holzhausen smashed two of the vehicle's “armor glass” windows on stage with a metal ball. Article Title: Why China is dropping Google's antitrust case, but not Nvidia and Intel's
Article Text:
Representational image.

Nvidia and Intel face maximum economic pressure

Google's blocked services limit Beijing's leverage





China has strategically dropped its antitrust investigation into Google while intensifying regulatory pressure on Nvidia and Intel, as Beijing selectively targets semiconductor companies that represent the most critical leverage points in escalating US-China trade negotiations. The decision to terminate the Google probe, which focused on Android's dominance among Chinese smartphone makers, comes as China simultaneously bans its tech giants from buying Nvidia's AI chips and pursues potential fines against the chipmaker that could reach billions of dollars.The State Administration for Market Regulation terminated its competition probe against Google's Android operating system dominance, which had targeted the platform's impact on Chinese smartphone makers like Oppo and Xiaomi , according to the Financial Times. The decision signals Beijing's tactical shift toward concentrating regulatory firepower on chipmakers rather than dispersing enforcement across multiple tech giants.The contrast highlights China's calculated targeting of companies where mutual economic dependence creates maximum negotiating leverage. Intel recorded $15.5 billion in Chinese sales during 2024, representing 29 percent of its global revenue and making China the chipmaker's largest market worldwide, surpassing the United States, the FT reported.Similarly, China accounted for 13 percent of Nvidia's global sales in the first three quarters of 2024, establishing it as the AI chipmaker's second-biggest market.SAMR this week determined Nvidia violated antitrust law during its 2020 acquisition of Mellanox Technologies, potentially exposing the company to fines between 1 and 10 percent of annual sales, according to the Financial Times.China's Cyberspace Administration simultaneously banned major domestic tech companies, including ByteDance and Alibaba, from purchasing Nvidia's RTX Pro 6000D chips specifically designed for the Chinese market.Google presents fundamentally different economics for Chinese regulators. The company's search engine has been blocked in China since 2010, along with most parent company Alphabet's core services. Google's primary Chinese revenue streams come from advertising sales to domestic companies targeting overseas markets and limited cloud services operations.The Asia-Pacific region contributed 17 percent of Alphabet's total sales in 2023, with China representing an undisclosed portion, the FT noted. This restricted market presence reduces both Google's vulnerability to Chinese regulatory action and Beijing's potential leverage during trade negotiations."Drop one case but seize the other," explained one person familiar with the matter. "China is trying to narrow its retaliatory targets to make them more potent" as US-China trade talks continue addressing tariffs, export controls and technology restrictions.
Article Summary: China terminates antitrust probe into Google while intensifying pressure on Nvidia and Intel. Beijing selectively targets semiconductor companies that represent critical leverage points in escalating US-China trade negotiations. China simultaneously bans its tech giants from buying Nvidia's AI chips and pursues potential fines against the chipmaker.

Article Title: How shareholders of this Chinese tech giant may be a 'problem' for Donald Trump’s TikTok deal

Why these ByteDance shareholders may be concerned by Trump’s TikTok deal

If this thing looks like it’s going to be majority owned or even close to it by the Chinese, Congress is going to go nuts. I just don’t see how they sell a company that is controlled using mostly ByteDance stock as equity,” the equity investor added,”





US President Donald Trump 's deal with TikTok is reportedly facing a last-minute obstacle. A report claims that major US investors, who are shareholders in ByteDance, the Chinese parent company of the short video app, may pose a hindrance. Key shareholders, including billionaire Jeff Yass, a prominent Trump backer, are concerned they could face significant US tax burdens or congressional backlash if they are forced to sell their stakes to buy into a new, US-controlled TikTok.According to a report by On The Money, insiders have claimed that investors such as Yass, Bill Ford of General Atlantic Partners, and private equity firm KKR are hoping to "roll" their current shares into the new US company. This would allow them to avoid paying potentially hefty capital gains taxes.However, this manoeuvre is creating a problem for the deal as Congress and tax regulations could oppose such an arrangement. To compare, Susquehanna reportedly holds about 15% of ByteDance, with General Atlantic believed to have a similar share. Meanwhile, KKR’s ownership is estimated at roughly 1.7%.The key issue in this deal is whether a roll-over aligns with the law requiring that TikTok remain under majority US control.On paper, Chinese shareholders could still end up holding most of the equity in the new entity once the 19.9% stake earmarked for ByteDance in mainland China is included. However, the White House maintains that the deal is consistent with the law.In a statement, a White House source said:However, others close to the negotiations are less convinced. Lawmakers are increasingly concerned that the arrangement may still breach legislation intended to ban TikTok unless it is fully separated from China.one prospective equity investor told On The Money.Meanwhile, China critics in Congress are reviewing the proposed US-led TikTok framework, with some still pushing for a shutdown over concerns about spying and harmful content for young users. Possible solutions include investors such as Yass, Ford, and KKR making new investments, partially rolling over their ByteDance shares, or transferring them fully into the new entity. Article Title: Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei warns US: Selling AI chips to China is ‘mortgaging our future’
Article Text:
National security risk



Clash with Trump administration



China’s strategic push







Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei has issued a warning in relation to the US AI chips. Speaking at the Axios AI+ DC Summit, the Anthropic CEO has urged the US government to again consider its plans to allow chipmakers Nvidia and AMD to continue selling their advanced AI chips to China. Amodie’s AI startup is backed by Jeff Bezos stressed on the fact that US’s dominance in the chip technology is its las strategic edge over China. “It may be the only advantage we have because we’re so far behind on things like munitions, ship building,” Amodei said, adding, “It is mortgaging our future as a country to sell these chips to China”.The comments from Amodei comes at the time when geopolitical tensions are rising and a controversial US proposal would allow chip exports to China, with a portion of the revenue redirected to the government. While this move from the US government aims to balance economic interest and national security, Amodei feels that this decision could lead catastrophic consequences. “This could control the fate of nations. This could control the future of freedom and democracy,” he warned.Amodei’s sharp stance on the matter of US AI chips has placed him at odds with the Trump administration, which has taken a more permissive approach to AI chip exports than some industry leaders expected.He criticized the policy shift, calling it: “The single most disastrous national security decision made in this term”.While the other tech CEO’s have agreed to the plan of the US government to export US AI chips, Amodei has emerged as a vocal dissenter, advocating for stricter safeguards on chip technology.The warning from Anthropic CEO is followed by China’s ban on major tech firms for purchasing Nvidia’s latest AI chipset. Along with this, China has also launched its anti-dumping investigation into the U.S. semiconductor sector, further escalating the tech rivalry.Despite acknowledging the risks posed by AI, Amodei stressed that the U.S. must maintain its lead in chip innovation to preserve its global influence. “Even with the dangers of the technology and the need for guardrails, defeating China in this field is crucial,” he said

Article Title: Who is Paramjit Singh, Indian-origin businessman detained by ICE for using a pay phone without paying
Article Text:
Photo: Newsweek

Who is Paramjit Singh

Why is Paramjit Singh detained

Not a first





US Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) has detained an Indian-origin businessman, Paramjit Singh for more than a month. According to a Newsweek report, Singh, who has been a green card holder for over 30 years, was held at Chicago O'Hare Airport in July. Paramjit Singh, who was then returning from an India trip, was detained citing an old incident when he used a pay phone without paying. Singh's attorney Luis Angeles told the publication that the detainment has been "nothing short of horrific" for him and his family.Paramjit Singh runs a business in Fort Wayne, Indiana for the past three decades. He has a brain tumour and heart condition. His family told local news station WPTA that he makes several trips to India for his treatment.Singh was detained by ICE on July 30 when he was returning from one such trip to India. As per reports, he was kept inside the airport for five days where his condition deteriorated to the point where he had to be taken to the emergency room (ER).Angeles told Newsweek that Paramjit’s family was not notified of the ER visit until they received a bill for his medical stay.As mentioned above, Paramjit Singh was detained over an old incident where he used a pay phone without making any payment.Angeles calls it a "minor infraction for which he has already taken full accountability, served his time, and paid his debt to society."Stating that efforts to secure his release have been “exhaustive but frustrating,” Angeles said“We filed for a bond redetermination and successfully won the bond hearing. However, DHS has continued to employ what I would describe as legal—yet arguably unethical—tactics to prolong his detention, despite being fully aware of his severe medical condition, which requires emergency surgery. The government is holding him without justifiable cause, exacerbating his health risks and causing immense distress to his family”.The Newsweek report says that Paramjit’s case is not an isolated incident. Several green card holders have been detained recently on the basis of their decades-old legal issues. The publication cites a similar case of Jemmy Jimenez Rosa, a Massachusetts mother who was held for 10 days based on a decades-old marijuana conviction. As per the report, she was taken to the hospital while being held in the airport without access to medication.
Article Summary: US Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) has detained an Indian-origin businessman, Paramjit Singh for more than a month. According to a Newsweek report, Singh, who has been a green card holder for over 30 years, was held at Chicago O'Hare Airport in July. He was detained over an old incident where he used a pay phone without making any payment.

Article Title: Intel gets $5 billion lifeline from Nvidia, 20 years after saying no to $20 billion deal
Article Text:
How Nvidia became the AI king Intel never saw coming

Intel's $20 billion mistake now becomes survival strategy





Twenty years after Intel rejected buying Nvidia for $20 billion, the roles have completely flipped: Nvidia is investing $5 billion in its struggling former takeover target and rescue Intel through a strategic chip partnership. The deal announced Thursday sees Nvidia purchasing Intel stock at $23.28 per share—a 6.5% discount—while the companies collaborate on PC and data center processors. Intel will embed Nvidia's cutting-edge graphics into consumer chips and manufacture specialized processors for Nvidia's AI systems.The partnership crystallises one of tech's most dramatic power shifts. Intel, once Silicon Valley's undisputed chip king with double Nvidia's revenue as recently as 2022, now has a market value under $100 billion. Nvidia has exploded to over $4 trillion, making it the world's second-most valuable company.Back in 2005, then-Intel CEO Paul Otellini pitched acquiring Nvidia to his board, recognizing that graphics chips might revolutionise data centers. Directors balked at the unprecedented price tag and Intel's poor acquisition track record, instead backing an internal project called Larrabee that burned hundreds of millions before collapsing in 2009.Nvidia seized the moment Intel missed. While Intel clung to traditional processors, Nvidia anticipated the AI revolution, developing specialised chips perfect for machine learning before ChatGPT made headlines. When tech giants raced to build AI infrastructure, they turned to Nvidia's ready-made solutions.Today, Nvidia approaches $200 billion in annual revenue—soon earning more each quarter than Intel generates yearly. Its data center business alone dwarfs entire chip companies.Intel has desperately chased the AI wave through acquisitions like Nervana Systems ($400 million) and Habana Labs ($2 billion), but gained little ground against Nvidia's dominance. New CEO Lip-Bu Tan, who replaced the ousted Pat Gelsinger this year, admits Intel won't compete with Nvidia's high-end systems "anytime soon."The Nvidia partnership represents pragmatic surrender disguised as collaboration. Intel acknowledges it needs the company it once could have owned to remain relevant in computing's AI-driven future."This historic collaboration tightly couples Nvidia's AI stack with Intel's x86 ecosystem," said Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang, diplomatic language for Intel's dependence on its former potential acquisition target.The investment follows recent lifelines including government backing and SoftBank's $2 billion injection as Intel struggles to fund its manufacturing ambitions.
Article Summary: Intel rejected a $20 billion bid for Nvidia in 2005. Now Nvidia is investing $5 billion in its struggling former takeover target. The deal sees Nvidia purchasing Intel stock at $23.28 per share. Intel will embed Nvidia's cutting- edge graphics into consumer chips.

Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg wears artificial intelligence-powered smart glasses as he speaks during the company's Connect developer conference.

Ray-Ban Meta (Gen 2) glasses price and features



Oakley Meta Vanguard glasses price and features



Meta Ray-Ban Display glasses price and features

At Meta's annual Connect event, Mark Zuckerberg unveiled a comprehensive new lineup of AI-powered glasses, including two new models and a new category. These products, developed in partnership with eyewear giants Ray-Ban and Oakley, are designed to integrate artificial intelligence (AI) into daily life.According to the company, the AI glasses are designed with three core values, including light, feel comfortable and great looks. They are loaded with AI technology, taking “superintelligence seriously”.“Our glasses are engineered to get better over time. As the AI improves, your glasses do, too. And because good things come in threes, we’ve got three major AI glasses announcements to share, the company said in a press note.The new Ray-Ban Meta (Gen 2) glasses build on the success of the previous model with key upgrades, Meta says, claiming that the battery life has been doubled to up to eight hours of mixed use, and the camera now records in ultra HD 3K video, capturing sharper and more vivid content.A new feature called “conversation focus” will help users hear better in noisy environments by using the glasses' open-ear speakers to amplify a person's voice.The second generation is available now, starting at $379, and comes in three new colours.For athletes and outdoor adventurers, Meta is introducing the new Oakley Meta Vanguard. These performance AI glasses are built for durability with an IP67 rating, making them sweatproof and resistant to temporary submersion. They feature a centered 12MP camera with a wide 122-degree field of view and up to nine hours of battery life, the company says.The open-ear speakers are 6 decibels louder than previous models and include advanced wind noise reduction. The glasses integrate with fitness apps like Garmin and Strava, providing real-time stats and an autocapture feature that automatically records videos at key workout milestones. The Oakley Meta Vanguard is available for pre-order at $499.The most significant announcement was the Meta Ray-Ban Display glasses, which introduce a new category of AI eyewear. These glasses are the first in the lineup to feature a high-resolution, full-colour monocular display built into the lens.According to Meta, the display, which disappears when not in use, has a resolution of 42 pixels per degree—higher than any of Meta’s consumer VR headsets—and a brightness of up to 5,000 nits. The glasses are controlled with the new Meta Neural Band, a wrist-worn device that uses surface electromyography (sEMG) to interpret subtle hand and finger movements.The system also allows users to view messages, take video calls, use pedestrian navigation, and see live captions, all without taking out their phone.The Meta Ray-Ban Display, which includes the Neural Band, is available for purchase on September 30 for $799.Zuckerberg also highlighted the social impact of the technology, noting that the AI glasses are being used by Blind and Low-Vision individuals and are being issued by VA Blind Rehabilitation Centers to help veterans navigate the world more independently.
Article Summary: The Meta Ray-Ban Display glasses are the first in the lineup to feature a high- resolution, full-colour monocular display built into the lens. Article Title: Harsh Goenka shares world’s fastest-growing jobs: From FinTech engineers to big data specialists; check the complete list
Article Text:
Big data specialists lead the surge, Harsh Goenka reveals

FinTech engineers on the rise

AI & machine learning specialists

Software & applications developers

Security management specialists

Data warehousing specialists

Emerging roles in technology and mobility



Autonomous & EV specialists (+45%): Focused on electric and self-driving vehicles, driving innovation in sustainable transportation.

UI & UX designers (+45%): Enhance user experience across digital platforms, combining design aesthetics with functionality.

Light truck or delivery services drivers (+45%): Demand is rising with e-commerce growth, requiring logistics expertise and efficiency.

Internet of Things (IoT) specialists (+40%): Develop connected devices and smart systems for homes, industries, and cities.

Data analysts & scientists (+40%): Convert complex datasets into actionable insights, supporting business strategy.

Environmental engineers (+40%): Address sustainability challenges, focusing on climate solutions and resource management.

Information security analysts (+40%): Protect organizations from cyberattacks and data breaches.

DevOps engineers (+40%): Ensure smooth software deployment and operations through automation and monitoring.

Renewable energy engineers (+40%): Drive the transition to sustainable energy systems and technologies.





Preparing for the future





The global job market is undergoing a dramatic transformation, driven by rapid advancements in artificial intelligence (AI), robotics, and data-driven technologies. Billionaire industrialist Harsh Goenka recently highlighted insights from the World Economic Forum’s 2025 Future of Jobs Report, which surveyed 1,043 companies representing over 14.1 million employees worldwide. The report forecasts that by 2030, roles such as Big Data Specialists are expected to grow by a staggering 110%, followed by FinTech Engineers at 95% and AI & Machine Learning Specialists at 85%.These projections reflect a global shift toward technology-focused careers, emphasizing the increasing demand for skills that support automation, AI integration, and data-driven decision-making. While the surge in certain sectors is promising, experts also warn that around 14% of workers may need to reskill due to automation, highlighting both opportunities and challenges in the evolving employment landscape.Big Data Specialists are projected to experience the highest growth, with an anticipated increase of +110% by 2030. This role has become the backbone of modern organizations, as businesses increasingly rely on data analytics to make informed decisions. Professionals in this field work with massive datasets, applying analytical tools, machine learning algorithms, and cloud computing platforms to extract actionable insights.The rise of AI, e-commerce, and cloud-based business models has amplified the demand for Big Data expertise, making it one of the most critical skill sets in the global economy. Companies across sectors—from healthcare to finance—seek data specialists to enhance efficiency, improve customer experiences, and stay competitive in a rapidly evolving marketplace.FinTech Engineers are expected to see +95% growth by 2030, driven by the expansion of digital payments, blockchain technologies, and financial automation. These specialists are crucial in designing and maintaining secure financial systems that cater to the needs of a global, digital-first economy. As banks and financial institutions adopt AI-powered decision-making, fraud detection, and personalized banking services, the need for skilled FinTech engineers has surged. Their expertise not only drives innovation but also ensures the scalability, reliability, and security of next-generation financial platforms. For aspiring professionals, this field represents a unique intersection of technology, finance, and problem-solving skills.AI and Machine Learning Specialists follow closely, with +85% growth expected. These roles involve designing algorithms and systems that can learn from data, automate complex processes, and predict outcomes. From autonomous vehicles to predictive healthcare tools, AI & ML professionals are shaping the future of virtually every industry. The demand for these specialists reflects organizations’ commitment to leveraging intelligent systems for efficiency and innovation. For students and career shifters, acquiring AI and ML skills offers long-term stability and opportunities across sectors such as robotics, energy, logistics, and entertainment.Software and Applications Developers are projected to grow +60% by 2030. They play a critical role in creating the platforms and applications that power businesses, entertainment, and everyday life. With increasing digitization, mobile-first solutions, and cloud computing adoption, the demand for skilled developers remains high. These professionals are expected to build scalable, user-friendly software while integrating AI, security, and performance optimization to meet modern enterprise needs.Security Management Specialists are expected to see +55% growth. As cyber threats evolve, organizations are investing heavily in cybersecurity to protect sensitive data, networks, and digital infrastructure. These specialists design, implement, and monitor security protocols to mitigate risks, ensuring operational continuity. The rise of remote work, cloud adoption, and IoT devices has made this role more critical than ever.Data Warehousing Specialists (+50%) manage the storage and organization of massive data repositories that organizations rely on for analytics and decision-making. With companies processing terabytes of data daily, these professionals ensure that information is accessible, reliable, and secure.These roles highlight the breadth of opportunities arising from digital transformation, AI adoption, and sustainability initiatives worldwide.Harsh Goenka emphasizes that understanding these trends is crucial for both job seekers and organizations. While technological advancements create new opportunities, they also underscore the importance of continuous learning, reskilling, and adaptability. Professionals who embrace emerging skill sets, especially in data, AI, and cybersecurity, will be well-positioned to thrive in the competitive, AI-driven global economy. Governments, educational institutions, and companies must also invest in training programs to ensure the workforce can meet the demands of the future, creating a resilient and future-ready talent pool.
Article Summary: The World Economic Forum’s 2025 Future of Jobs Report surveyed 1,043 companies representing over 14.1 million employees worldwide. Big Data Specialists are projected to experience the highest growth, with an anticipated increase of +110% by 2030. FinTech Engineers are expected to see +95% growth by 2030, driven by the expansion of digital payments and blockchain technologies.

Article Title: Tesla CEO Elon Musk responds to Pope Leo’s criticism of trillion-dollar pay package with this Bible verse
Article Text:
Tesla’s trillion dollar plan



Elon Musk’s scriptural response







Tesla CEO and billionaire entrepreneur Elon Musk has finally responded to the criticism from Pope Leo XIV over Tesla’s proposed $1 trillion pay compensation package with a sharp Bible verse. Musk’s response to Pope’s criticism has started a global debate on wealth, corporate ambition and morality. The controversy started when Pope Leo, the first American-born pontiff raised questions on Musk’s potential rise as the world’s first trillionaire.In a recent interview with The Crux, the Pope said, “Yesterday the news that Elon Musk is going to be the first trillionaire in the world. What does that mean, and what’s that about? If that is the only thing that has value anymore, then we’re in big trouble”. He linked Elon Musk’s pay package to the growing income inequality. He mentioned that the CEO’s earn 600 times more as compared to an average worker. The pontiff warned that such disparities reflect a dangerous shift in societal values.Tesla proposed a compensation plan which would award Musk up to 423.7 million shares over a decade. The chairperson of Tesla's board of directors, Robyn Denholm, has defended Musk’s new multibillion-dollar compensation plan.The plan, which could be the largest in corporate history, was unveiled in a regulatory filing last week. In a recent interview with The New York Times, at Tesla’s engineering headquarters in California, Denholm said that Musk's compensation should depend on his ability to achieve "seemingly impossible goals. " She stated that Musk is capable of delivering world-changing technology if he is driven by these ambitious targets, even as the company faces a drop in sales and profits.“Putting together any compensation plan, you need to look at what motivates the individual that you’re trying to motivate. And for Elon, it’s doing things that no one else has done before,” Denholm said when asked about Musk’s proposed pay package.Tesla CEO Elon Musk has now responded to Pope’s criticism by sharing a Bible Verse in a post on X (formerly known as twitter). “Why do you see the speck in your neighbor’s eye, but do not notice the log in your own eye?” wrote Musk.The verse shared by Musk has been interred as a jab at the Vatican’s own wealth which is estimated to be $2 trillion.
Article Summary: Pope Leo XIV raised questions on Musk's potential rise as the world’s first trillionaire. Tesla proposed a compensation plan which would award Musk up to 423.7 million shares over a decade. “Why do you see the speck in your neighbor's eye, but do not notice the log in your own eye?” wrote Musk.

Article Title: ‘How could anyone not love’, asks Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang as he praises Google Gemini Nano Banana; Sundar Pichai reacts
Article Text:
A viral moment and Sundar Pichai ’s reaction

Jensen Huang’s AI arsenal





Internet is recently obsessed with Google Gemini’s Nano Banana image creation tool. Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang is the latest one to join the fan following of Google Gemini Nano Banana. Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang has all the praises for Google Gemini’s latest AI image generator, Nano Banana. Speaking to the Wired in an interview, Huang was not able to contain his enthusiasm, “How could anyone not love Nano Banana? I mean Nano Banana, how good is that? Tell me it’s not true!”The tool, which was launched recently enabled users to make precise edits to AI-generated images while preserving the integrity of faces, animals, and background elements. Google Labs VP Josh Woodward recently revealed that Nano Banana started a surge of over 300 million images in early September making it immensely popular.Huang’s animated endorsement quickly went viral, prompting a response from Google CEO Sundar Pichai. After Google DeepMind’s Nicole Brichtova shared a post on social media platform X (formerly known as Twitter) that , “Jensen Huang being a Nano Banana fan made my day,” Pichai quote-tweeted with a simple reply: “Mine too.”This exchange added a playful twist to an otherwise high-stakes week in AI, as Nvidia joined other tech giants in announcing major investments in UK-based data centers and AI research.As per the report by Wired, Nvidia has committed an investment of $683 million to center builder Nscale, projecting over $68 billion in revenue over six years.Apart from Nano Banana, Huang also shared the insights abut how he uses AI tools in his daily life. Huang revealed that for technical tasks he prefer Google Gemini and for artistic projects he uses Grok. He also mentioned that for fast research he finds Perplexity useful and his everyday tasks are handled by ChatGPT. “I use it every day, and it’s improved my learning, my thinking… I have the benefit of using all the AI—how good is that?” he said.Huang also described a workflow where he give the same prompts to various AI agents and asks them to critique each other’s responses before selecting the best one. “It’s a thinking partner… and it saves me a ton of time,” Huang explained.

Huang also shared the insights abut how he uses AI tools in his daily life.

Article Title: Google and Paypal announce partnership to deploy AI-powered solutions across platforms
Article Text:
AI meets fintech







In a strategic move Google has partnered with PayPal . As reported by Reuters, as part of this association the company will offer AI-powered solutions across their platforms. This partnership aims to improve user experiences, unlock new capabilities and streamline operations. According to the Reuters report, this partnership will use Google Cloud’s advanced AI tools — including Vertex AI and Duet AI—to enhance PayPal’s internal operations and customer-facing services.Under the partnership:- Paypal will adopt Vertex AI to create and deploy custom machine learning models for customer engagement, fraud detection and operational efficiency.- Duet AI, Google’s productivity assistant embedded in Workspace, will be rolled out to Paypal employees to streamline workflows and boost collaboration.- The companies aim to deliver more personalised, secure and intelligent payment experiences for users worldwide.Srini Venkatesan, PayPal’s CTO, said the partnership will “accelerate innovation” and help deliver “more intelligent experiences” to users. Thomas Kurian, CEO of Google Cloud, emphasized the shared goal of bringing generative AI to every industry, calling the collaboration “a powerful example of what’s possible when two leaders join forces.”The move reflects a growing trend among tech and fintech firms to embed generative AI into core operations—from customer service and fraud prevention to internal productivity and software development. As AI becomes central to digital transformation, partnerships like this one signal a future where intelligent automation is the norm, not the exception.
Article Summary: Google has partnered with PayPal to offer AI-powered solutions across their platforms. This partnership aims to improve user experiences, unlock new capabilities and streamline operations. The move reflects a growing trend among tech and fintech firms to embed generative AI into core operations.

Article Title: US immigration authority: We are introducing new test for citizenship applicants
Article Text:
Poll Should stricter rules for naturalization be implemented? Yes, necessary for integrity No, it is too harsh



USCIS rolls out stricter rules







USCIS or the US Citizenship and Immigration Services has announced a new version of the naturalization civics test that will take effect in 2025. In a press release, the immigration authority said it has posted a Federal Register notice announcing implementation of the 2025 naturalization civics test. The new test is part of the process immigrants must go through to become US citizens. It is aimed to measure the applicant’s knowledge of US history and government, as required by the law.“The 2025 test assesses an alien’s understanding of U.S. history and government in line with the statutory requirement and is one of many steps in an ongoing effort to restore integrity to the naturalization process and meet congressional intent,” USCIS said adding “Naturalization is a privilege that allows aliens to become fully vested members of American society, with important rights and responsibilities that all citizens should exercise and respect. ”USCIS Spokesperson Matthew Tragesser said “American citizenship is the most sacred citizenship in the world and should only be reserved for aliens who will fully embrace our values and principles as a nation.”“By ensuring only those aliens who meet all eligibility requirements, including the ability to read, write, and speak English and understand U.S. government and civics, are able to naturalize, the American people can be assured that those joining us as fellow citizens are fully assimilated and will contribute to America’s greatness.These critical changes are the first of many,” he added.The immigration agency has also rolled out stricter rules, such as tougher reviews for disability-based exemptions from test requirements, closer checks on applicants’ moral character, and neighborhood investigations to verify eligibility. In addition, USCIS said that it is resuming neighborhood investigations to ensure that aliens meet statutory requirements and are worthy of U.S. citizenship.Other recent policies include clarifying that unlawfully voting, unlawfully registering to vote, and making false claims to U.S. citizenship disqualify aliens from showing good moral character.
Article Summary: USCIS has announced a new version of the naturalization civics test that will take effect in 2025. The new test is part of the process immigrants must go through to become US citizens. It is aimed to measure the applicant’s knowledge of US history and government.

Article Title: How Tata became Apple's biggest Indian ‘weapon’ against China
Article Text:
Tata scales iPhone production as Apple expands India manufacturing

US-China trade tensions drive Apple's iPhone production shift to India





Tata Electronics has positioned itself as Apple 's most significant manufacturing partner in India, capitalising on the iPhone maker's efforts to reduce dependence on Chinese production for the US market.Regulatory filings reviewed by ET reveal that Apple's iPhone shipments to the US now represent nearly 37% of Tata Electronics' FY25 revenue, generating over Rs 23,112 crore for the Indian manufacturer. The shift marks a strategic pivot from the previous year, when Tata assembled iPhones exclusively for Taiwan and domestic consumption.The transformation has delivered substantial financial returns for the Tata Group subsidiary. Consolidated operating income reached Rs 66,206 crore in FY25, up from Rs 3,752 crore the previous year. Tata Electronics Systems Solutions, formerly the Wistron facility acquired in March 2024, reported revenues of Rs 75,367 crore during the 15-month period through March 2025, compared with Rs 14,350 crore in 2023.Apple is manufacturing all four iPhone 17 models across five Indian factories, including recently operational plants, Bloomberg reported. This represents the first instance of all new iPhone variants shipping from India at product launch.Manufacturing capacity controlled by Tata Group is expected to account for up to half of India's total iPhone output over the next two years, according to industry sources cited by Bloomberg. The expansion includes Tata's facility in Tamil Nadu's Hosur and Foxconn Technology Group's production hub near Bangalore airport.The company has strengthened its position through strategic acquisitions. Beyond the Wistron purchase, Tata Electronics acquired a 60% controlling stake in Pegatron Technology India for Rs 1,650 crore in January.Apple's production realignment coincides with ongoing US-China trade tensions and tariff policies implemented under the Trump administration. iPhone exports from India totalled $7.5 billion during the four-month period beginning April 2025, representing significant acceleration from $17 billion exported during the entire previous fiscal year.Apple Chief Executive Tim Cook has committed to $600 billion in US investments over four years, a pledge industry observers view as aimed at maintaining tariff exemptions for India-manufactured devices. Cook previously stated that over 70% of iPhones sold in the US market are now produced in India.The manufacturing shift follows Apple's broader strategy to reduce supply chain concentration in China, a process accelerated by pandemic-related disruptions and geopolitical tensions. Tata Group has emerged as the sole Indian company in Apple's iPhone assembly ecosystem, competing primarily with Taiwan's Foxconn for market share.
Article Summary: Apple's iPhone shipments to the US now represent nearly 37% of Tata Electronics' FY25 revenue. Apple is manufacturing all four iPhone 17 models across five Indian factories, including recently operational plants. This represents the first instance of all new iPhone variants shipping from India at product launch.

Article Title: GitHub CEO Thomas Dohmke: At GitHub, all employees have a specific non-negotiable, which is using ...
Article Text:
AI usage as a performance metric



Mindset over metrics







At GitHub, it is important and mandatory for the employees to use artificial intelligence tools. As reported by Business Insider, Github CEO Thomas Dohmke has made it clear that every GitHub employee irrespective of their role are expected to actively use AI tools such as GitHub Copilot as part of their daily work routine. “There is no world where I would allow for somebody to say, ‘Well, sorry, I don’t want to use GitHub,’” Dohmke said on a recent episode of the Decoder podcast. “It’s part of our company culture that everybody at GitHub uses GitHub.”As per the report, Dohmke’s comments came in defense of a Microsoft memo which asked the managers to evaluate employees on the basis of their use of internal AI tools. The authored by Microsoft executive Julia Liuson, stated that AI usage should be part of “holistic reflections” on employee performance.“AI is now a fundamental part of how we work,” the memo read. “Just like collaboration, data-driven thinking, and effective communication, using AI is no longer optional—it’s core to every role and every level.”Dohmke supports the same sentiment and feels that it’s totally fair to ask employees to reflect on their AI usage. “Did you use GitHub Copilot or Microsoft Copilot, Teams Copilot to summarize a meeting, and if not, why not?” he asked.As per the report, Dohmke also clarified that measuring AI usage is not about counting the lines of code written with the help of copilot. But it is about building a mindset which foster continuous learning and adaptation.He also stressed on the fact that the expectation from employees to use the internal AI tools is across departments ranging from engineering to HR, legal, and sales. “If the employee doesn’t want that, then there’s tens of thousands of other tech companies out there where they can have that,” Dohmke said.
Article Summary: GitHub CEO Thomas Dohmke has made it clear that every GitHub employee irrespective of their role are expected to actively use AI tools such as GitHub Copilot. “There is no world where I would allow for somebody to say, ‘Well, sorry, I don’t want to use GitHub,’” he said.
